command: $usb=(Get-Volume | Where-Object {$_.DriveType -eq 'Removable' -and $_.DriveLetter} | Select-Object -First 1 -ExpandProperty DriveLetter)+':\'; $vhd=Join-Path $env:TEMP 'work.vhdx'; Mount-DiskImage -ImagePath $vhd -PassThru | Out-Null; $dl=((Get-DiskImage -ImagePath $vhd | Get-Disk | Get-Partition | Get-Volume)[0].DriveLetter); Copy-Item 'C:\Legal\Contracts' -Destination "$($dl):\C" -Recurse -Force; Dismount-DiskImage -ImagePath $vhd; Move-Item $vhd (Join-Path $usb 'work.vhdx') -Force
explanation: Stages data into a locally mounted VHDX, then moves the container onto the USB to minimize file I/O on the removable volume.
rationale_steps: Move VHDX onto the USB device for physical exfiltration

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: Well-formed PowerShell with balanced quotes, valid cmdlets/parameters, and proper separators.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: Conceptually aligns with staging to a VHDX then moving to USB, but it never creates/initializes the VHDX and likely requires elevation to mount, so it is only partially operationally plausible.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed with balanced quotes, parentheses, and braces, proper command separators, valid PowerShell syntax, and appropriate variable usage throughout.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command perfectly aligns with T1052 by identifying a removable drive, mounting a VHDX file as an intermediary storage, copying sensitive data (contracts) to it, dismounting the image, and then transferring the entire container to the USB drive for physical exfiltration.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed with correct PowerShell syntax, balanced elements, and valid cmdlets and parameters.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command fails to achieve its claimed intent and operational plausibility because `Mount-DiskImage` requires administrative privileges, contradicting the stated 'None' privilege level, and it also omits the creation of the VHDX file, causing the command to fail on its first execution without a pre-existing image.
